content.S:
Below is the Australian Nepalese Multicultural Centre (ANMC) Treasures Report for the year ending 30 June 2020.

The financial report comprises of two financial years data since ANMC did not have AGM for the year ending 30 June 2019 due to pandemic. Two AGMs were merged in one for time unlike previous years and it had to be held for the purpose of election and reporting requirement. The audit report for both financial years has been included in the report. The balance sheet shows a bank balance of AUD31,041.56 in ANZ bank and AUD 36,223.77 in NAB. Total assets including cash at bank, Land & Building and plant equipment is AUD 1,587,579.24 whereas our liability is AUD 484,082.56 which included a Bank loan of AUD450,000.00 ANMC made a profit of AUD 273,067.54 for the year ending 30 June 2019, and AUD 121,221.32 for the year ending 30 June 2020 respectively.

The main sources of income are Donation which is AUD 88,319.76 Family Membership AUD 26,851.17 and Individual Membership AUD 1,636.36 and fundraising AUD 7,136.77.

Australian Nepalese Multicultural Center (ANMC) is currently looking for a "Member Service Officer (MSO).

The purpose of this role to provide a range of services to members of Australian Nepalese Multicultural Centre (ANMC) and support Executive Committee and sub-committees for executing its set goals.

Reporting to the Treasurer/President/Secretary, the MSO will be required to assist in a wide range of functions with an emphasis on management of members‚Äô account in recognized accounting software; maintaining members register, follow up of unpaid membership fees/pledged amount, handling enquires and assist Executive Committee and various sub-committees on membership drive, and fundraising campaign.

This is a role that requires a capable, self-motivated person with a passion to work in a community-based organization.

Please refer to PD for more details.

Dear community leaders,

We would like to thank all of you for your ongoing support and guidance to the ANMC team.

We are pleased to share the good news that Hume Council has decided to grant planning permission for a place of worship and related activities at 100 Duncans Lanes, Diggers Rest.  We are now 100% certain that we can have our temples and multicultural hub at 100 Duncans Lane, Diggers Rest. We came across many obstacles in the journey, as the site we bought had Melbourne airport overlay and the land was meant for farming activities. Considering the constraints we had, the outcome we have today is amazing. We couldn't have done it without the collective efforts of various committees, valued life members, external consultants, volunteers and donors. Thank you all for your patience, continuous support and trust in the ANMC team.

Our initial strategy was to begin with temporary facilities and build further structures in several stages. In line with the approved planning permit proposal, we now aim to modify the existing structure and make it suitable for temporary temples and mediation halls.

We are organizing a Grand Gala Dinner and Live Music on 25th June. Like any other program, this event will have no meaning without the support from all of you. We request you to book the tickets for the event. Please try to bring as many people as possible from your area who haven't yet become a member of ANMC. We should encourage such individuals and families to become life members of ANMC during the Gala Dinner. Building a community centre is our collective responsibility and no one from our community should be left out of this noble cause.

Please click on the link below to reserve your seat as early as possible since we need to plan for the event based on the number of participants:

Book your tickets for the event

The entry fee for the event is $75 for each individual and children below 14 are not allowed. Group booking of 10 can be done for $700 which will give you a saving of $50 instead of booking it individually.

content.S:
The Australian Nepalese Multicultural Centre (ANMC), based in Victoria, Australia, has officially welcomed its new leadership. Dr. Tilak Pokharel assumed the role of President, succeeding outgoing President Gandhi Bhattarai, during the Annual General Meeting (AGM) held on Sunday, the 23rd of February 2025. The AGM, hosted in a hybrid format, took place within the premises of the multicultural center itself.

During the meeting, reports from both the President and Treasurer were reviewed and approved by attendees. Significant resolutions were also passed, including a new requirement mandating that future presidential candidates must have previously served at least one term on the executive committee. Additionally, it was decided that the executive committee could appoint four nominated members. Former Presidents Dr Chandradipak Pokharel and Rajesh Acharya were also present at the AGM.

In his inaugural speech, President Dr. Tilak Pokharel committed to completing ongoing construction projects, initiating the construction of a new community hall, enhancing transparency within the organization, and fostering stronger collaboration with government entities. He emphasized that achieving the strategic goals of the Centre would involve extensive consultation and guidance from the community.

Joining President Pokharel on the new executive committee are Vice Presidents Keshav Kandel and Prabha Shrestha, Secretary Sudhir Shakya, Joint Secretary Deepak Acharya, Treasurer Arjun Dhakal, and Assistant Treasurer Manisha Aryal. Members elected to the committee include Evan Subedi, Parshuram Sharma Luitel, Prem Kandel, Prince Bhandari, Ruby Thapa Magar, and Sabita Adhikari.

The AGM concluded with President Pokharel expressing gratitude to outgoing President Gandhi Bhattarai, presenting him with a token of appreciation for his dedicated service. Additionally, former President Dr. Chandradipak Pokharel symbolically handed over soil from Lumbini to President Dr. Tilak Pokharel, marking the continuity and symbolic transfer of leadership.

On a lively evening of 29th March, the Australian Nepalese Multicultural Centre (ANMC) enjoyed being part of the Craigieburn Brigade Soccer Club‚Äôs Gala Dinner and Award Night. It was a fantastic event filled with excitement, celebration, and a strong community spirit.

Representing ANMC, our President, Dr Tilak Pokharel, attended the evening to celebrate the club‚Äôs achievements and connect with community members. Dr Pokharel warmly congratulated Madhab Paudel and the dedicated club team for putting together such a well-organised event. The evening beautifully showcased the club‚Äôs numerous accomplishments and the passion its members bring to the field.

Speaking at the event, Dr Pokharel shared, ‚ÄúEvents like these remind us how sports can positively impact our lives‚Äînot only by keeping us physically fit but also mentally healthy and socially connected.‚Äù He highlighted that choosing sports is a great way for everyone, especially younger generations, to become involved and stay engaged with the broader community.

Dr Pokharel also discussed ANMC‚Äôs vision of working closely with local sporting clubs to increase community engagement and make the best use of shared facilities. He encouraged everyone present to start conversations soon, exploring how ANMC and local clubs, including the Craigieburn Brigade Sports Club, can collaborate effectively.

The gala night was not just about awards; it celebrated sportsmanship, community, and togetherness. ANMC congratulates all those recognised on the night‚Äîboth award winners and nominees‚Äîfor their inspiring commitment and dedication.

We at ANMC are excited about the possibilities ahead and look forward to growing these community connections, supporting more great events, and helping build a vibrant, active, and united community for all.

content.S:
Despite soaring temperatures, the Australian Nepalese Multicultural Center (ANMC) proudly hosted a day-long MahaShivaratri celebration that drew a large and enthusiastic crowd. From early morning prayers to cultural performances, the event offered a vibrant glimpse into Nepali traditions and community spirit.

The formal program, held in the evening, included dignitaries, community leaders, and special guests who addressed the audience and shared their insights on the importance of preserving our cultural heritage. Traditional music and dance performances further enriched the festivities, delighting attendees of all ages.

Throughout the day, volunteers worked tirelessly‚Äîmanaging information booths, guiding visitors, and ensuring everyone remained hydrated and comfortable in the heat. Their commitment and hard work were critical to the event‚Äôs success.

Highlights of the celebration included:

  • Devotional Prayers and Rituals: Devotees gathered for offerings and prayers dedicated to Lord Shiva, reflecting the spiritual essence of MahaShivaratri.
  • Cultural Performances: Traditional Nepali dance and singers (bhajans and chantings) took the stage, captivating audiences with their lively music and colorful attire.
  • Community Engagement: Families and individuals from diverse backgrounds came together, showcasing the unity and inclusive spirit that ANMC strives to promote.
  • Formal Evening Program: Community leaders, special guests, and the ANMC Executive Committee shared messages of support, unity, and gratitude, highlighting the significance of the day‚Äôs festivities.

On behalf of ANMC, we extend our sincere appreciation to all attendees, volunteers, sponsors, and performers who contributed their time and energy to make this event a success. We also thank our community members for their unwavering support and enthusiasm, even in challenging weather conditions.

As we continue to celebrate and preserve Nepali culture in Victoria, we look forward to hosting more events that bring people together, foster cultural exchange, and strengthen our community bonds.

Thank you once again for making our MahaShivaratri celebration a truly memorable occasion.

content.S:
On 15th March 2025, Federation Square came alive with the vibrant sights and sounds of Nepali culture during the Nepal Festival Melbourne 2025. Proudly organised by the Non-Resident Nepali Association (NRNA), Victoria State Coordination Committee, the festival attracted thousands of visitors, showcasing the richness of Nepali culture through displays, performances, and community activities.

Established in 2014, the Australian Nepalese Multicultural Center (ANMC) has continuously aimed at preserving and promoting Nepali culture and heritage in Australia. This year, ANMC proudly led the festival's cultural display and decoration, significantly contributing to the festival's overall success and cultural authenticity.

ANMC's cultural display included two major attractions‚ÄîBibaha Mandap and Nepal House‚Äîboth of which captivated festival attendees.

Bibaha Mandap featured a life-sized traditional Nepali wedding pavilion, providing visitors an authentic glimpse into Nepali marriage customs and rituals. According to Narayan Dahal, the Bibaha Mandap received enthusiastic praise from visitors who admired the traditional aesthetics and educational insights.

Nepal House was the festival‚Äôs centerpiece, drawing crowds eager to explore Nepali culture deeply. The main highlight was the magnificent, large-sized replica of Janaki Temple from Janakpur, constructed meticulously by Narayan Kandel. Expressing his joy and honour, Kandel said, "I'm very happy and honoured to showcase the temple, and it is gratifying to see visitors appreciating our team's hard work."

Within Nepal House, visitors discovered diverse displays such as the vibrant portrayal of Ropai (traditional rice planting), the Lord Buddha statue, historical exhibits on the bravery of Gurkhas, authentic Nepali musical instruments, traditional Nepali items, paintings, and information highlighting unique tourism destinations in Nepal.

Dr Tilak Pokharel, President of ANMC, expressed immense delight in ANMC's leadership role in the festival's cultural decoration and displays. Dr Pokharel noted, "The Janaki Temple became the most photographed spot during the Nepal Festival and attracted significant media attention. Visitors overwhelmingly praised ANMC's dedication and creativity."

Prativa Shaha shared her thoughts, saying, "Cultural display has been one of the main objectives of the Nepal Festival, and it feels good to showcase our culture to those genuinely interested."

The success of Nepal Festival Melbourne 2025 not only celebrated Nepali traditions but also reinforced the ANMC‚Äôs mission of cultural preservation and education in Australia. ANMC remains committed to continuing these efforts, building stronger connections within the multicultural tapestry of Victoria.

title.S: Nepal Festival Melbourne 2025: ANMC Proudly Highlights Nepali Heritage

content.S:
On 17th March 2025, the Australian Nepalese Multicultural Center (ANMC) had the honor of hosting Her Excellency Chitralekha Yadav, Ambassador of Nepal to Australia, along with her partner, Dr. Shree Krishna Yadav, and the Honorary Consul of Nepal to Victoria, Nirajan Gauli.

The distinguished guests were warmly received by ANMC President Dr. Tilak Pokharel, accompanied by Vice President Keshav Kandel, Secretary Sudhir Shakya, Executive Committee member Rubi Thapa Magar, and NRNA Victoria Coordinator Mani Ratan Sapkota. The visitors were welcomed with traditional rituals conducted by ANMC priest Milan Gyawali and Baal Byas Shrawan Neupane, who performed religious rites and offered tika and blessings.

Ambassador Yadav expressed heartfelt joy and gratitude upon visiting the ANMC temple, remarking how blessed she felt being able to worship at a Nepali temple on foreign soil. She received tika and prasad and shared her profound appreciation for the spiritual and cultural presence the ANMC offers to the Nepali community in Australia.

During her visit, President Dr. Pokharel briefed Ambassador Yadav about ANMC's inspiring journey and extensive activities. Highlighting the preliminary master plan for ANMC's future, Dr. Pokharel emphasized the community's goal to build a multipurpose community hall. This initiative aims to meet the increasing demands of Victoria's growing Nepali population and to preserve and promote Nepal's rich culture and heritage. Dr. Pokharel requested Ambassador Yadav's assistance in facilitating connections with Nepalese government officials, specifically to aid in sourcing culturally significant artifacts for the proposed museum within the community hall.

Vice President Keshav Kandel emphasized the essential role of the Nepalese Embassy in collaborating with the Nepal Tourism Board and the Nepalese government to support and enrich ANMC's initiatives.

Ambassador Yadav enthusiastically pledged her support to ANMC, emphasizing that acquiring such significant land for the Nepali community was a commendable and proud achievement. She suggested that major Nepali cultural festivals and events in Australia should be centralized at the ANMC in the future, promising active facilitation from her office with the Nepalese government.

Honorary Consul Nirajan Gauli also assured his cooperation, pledging to work collaboratively with the Nepalese Embassy in Canberra to strengthen ANMC‚Äôs ties with both the Nepalese and Australian governments.

Adding historical context to the gathering, retired British Gurkha Bharansher Rai highlighted Nepal‚Äôs invaluable contributions to Australia during World Wars I and II, sharing compelling narratives of Nepalese Gurkhas who bravely fought alongside Australian soldiers and assisted significantly in freeing captured Australian troops.

Concluding the visit, Dr. Pokharel extended an invitation to Ambassador Yadav to attend ANMC's upcoming Teej event, which she graciously accepted, demonstrating ongoing support and strengthening bonds between the ANMC and the Embassy of Nepal.

ANMC is immensely grateful to Her Excellency Chitralekha Yadav and all distinguished guests for their visit, support, and dedication to the Nepalese community in Victoria, Australia.

excerpt.S: On 17th March 2025, the Australian Nepalese Multicultural Center (ANMC) had the honor of hosting Her Excellency...

title.S: Nepalese Ambassador Her Excellency Chitralekha Yadav Visits ANMC

content.S:
Harmony Day celebrates cultural diversity, highlighting the unity and respect among different communities in Australia. In keeping with this spirit, the Australian Nepalese Multicultural Centre (ANMC) proudly hosted a group of around 50 visitors from the Hume Interfaith Network on the 22nd of March 2025.

ANMC President Dr Tilak Pokharel, joined by Executive Committee members Prem Prasad Kandel, Rubi Thapa, and respected spiritual leader Baal Byas Guru Shrawan Neupane, warmly welcomed the guests. They shared insights about the centre‚Äôs ongoing activities, purpose, and community engagements. Guests were also given an interactive tour of ANMC's facilities.

Prominent community leader Madhuri Maskey enriched the visit by sharing meaningful insights into the rich Hindu and Buddhist cultural traditions of Nepal. This interaction provided valuable cultural context and helped strengthen mutual understanding and appreciation.

Members of the Hume Interfaith Network expressed their admiration for ANMC‚Äôs dedicated efforts towards promoting multicultural harmony and contributing significantly to the diverse community fabric of Victoria.

Concluding the event, President Dr Pokharel thanked the Hume Interfaith Network for their visit, emphasising how such exchanges are essential in fostering stronger community bonds and promoting social harmony.

At ANMC, we remain committed to celebrating diversity and building bridges of mutual respect and unity across communities.

content.S:
The Australian Nepalese Multicultural Centre (ANMC) attended the inauguration ceremony of the new Consulate Office of Nepal in Glenroy, Melbourne, on the 16th of March 2025. The event marked a significant milestone for the Nepali diaspora in Victoria, offering improved access and diplomatic representation in a convenient location.

The inauguration was conducted by Her Excellency, the Ambassador of Nepal, Chitra Lekha Yadav, who also led a special flag-raising ceremony. During this event, the Ambassador raised the Nepali flag, while Kathleen Matthews-Ward raised the Australian flag, symbolising the friendship and collaboration between Nepal and Australia.

ANMC President Dr Tilak Pokharel, a few ANMC patrons, ANMC team members, and several community leaders attended the event. The strong turnout highlighted the organisation's commitment to engaging proactively with diplomatic initiatives beneficial to the Nepali community.

During the ceremony, Dr Pokharel delivered a congratulatory speech recognising the importance of the consulate's role in uniting the Nepali community. He emphasised the necessity for a unified voice when representing Nepal on broader platforms, including political leadership and community advocacy.

Dr Pokharel acknowledged the tireless efforts of various community organisations but stressed the need for greater collaboration and strategic thinking focused on long-term community interests. He advocated for ANMC's potential to act as a central representative body for addressing collective issues faced by the Nepalese diaspora in Victoria.

Further, Dr Pokharel called on the newly inaugurated consulate to facilitate or even lead initiatives aimed at fostering unity, collaboration, and a cohesive representation of Nepali community interests. His remarks highlighted ANMC's readiness to actively participate and support the consulate in achieving these objectives.

ANMC congratulates the consulate on this significant achievement and looks forward to continued partnership for the betterment of the Nepali community in Victoria.

title.S: ANMC Attends Inauguration of Nepali Consulate Office in Melbourne

content.S:
On 6th April 2025, the Australian Nepalese Multicultural Centre (ANMC) hosted a heartfelt celebration of Ram Nawami, marking the birth of Lord Ram with devotion, unity, and cultural pride. The event brought together members of the Nepalese community in Melbourne to honour this important occasion in the Hindu calendar.

The celebration began with a special prayer (puja) dedicated to Lord Ram, followed by collective chanting of bhajans and mantras.

Alongside the spiritual activities, the event also featured storytelling by Baal Byas Shrawan Neupane, and shared reflections on the values Lord Ram represents‚Äîtruth, duty, respect, and compassion. These moments reminded everyone of the continuing relevance of Ram‚Äôs teachings in everyday life.

The gathering was not just a religious observance, but also an opportunity for the community to come together, reconnect, and celebrate shared heritage. ANMC thanks all volunteers and attendees for making the event meaningful and memorable.

We look forward to continuing these cultural celebrations that keep our traditions alive and strengthen the bonds within our diverse multicultural community.

Nepali New Year 2082: Greetings and Gathering Event

On the auspicious occasion of Nepali New Year 2082, ANMC is organising a greetings exchange and gathering event. Join us as we share warm wishes, foster community spirit, and joyfully welcome the new year.

Event Highlights:

Exchange of New Year Greetings
Chiyapaan (Nepali style light refreshments)
Family and Community Interaction

Date: Sunday, 13 April 2025
Time: 2 PM
Venue: ANMC Premises

We warmly invite everyone, along with their family and friends, to attend and make this event memorable.

Let's celebrate and embrace the new year together

Australian Nepalese Multicultural Center (ANMC) to receive $385,000 funding if Labor Government is re-elected

The Australian Nepalese Multicultural Center (ANMC) has welcomed a major election commitment from the Federal Member for Hawke, Sam Rae MP. During his visit to ANMC in Diggers Rest on 13 April 2025, Mr Rae announced that a re-elected Federal Labor Government will invest $385,000 in the development of key infrastructure at the centre.

This funding will be used to build:

  • A fully equipped commercial kitchen
  • A cool room to support food storage during large events
  • A dedicated dining area to accommodate community gatherings

These new facilities will help ANMC expand its ability to host large-scale cultural, religious and social events - strengthening its role as a central hub for the Nepalese community and beyond.

Sam Rae has been a strong supporter of ANMC and the local Nepalese community. This was not his first visit. Over the years, he has seen the centre‚Äôs transformation from a small space to a vibrant venue for multicultural exchange and celebration.

Speaking at the event, Sam Rae MP said:

‚ÄúThis is a fantastic investment in our vibrant Nepalese community here in Hawke.
This will ensure they have the facilities needed to celebrate and share their rich culture.
Only a Federal Labor Government can be trusted to continue delivering for our local multicultural community.‚Äù

ANMC President Dr Tilak Pokharel welcomed the announcement with appreciation and optimism. He highlighted the significance of this funding for the long-term sustainability of the centre.

‚ÄúWe are thankful to Sam Rae MP and the Federal Labor team for recognising the hard work of our volunteers and community members.
This commitment will help us create the infrastructure we need to serve the growing Nepalese community in Melbourne.
It‚Äôs a step towards deeper collaboration between the Nepali community and the Australian Government.‚Äù

Once delivered, these upgrades will allow ANMC to:

  • Host larger and more inclusive festivals and community celebrations
  • Offer better catering and dining facilities during events
  • Ensure food safety, storage and service at a professional standard

ANMC thanks all community members, volunteers and leaders who continue to contribute to its growth. This announcement is a recognition of that collective effort.

We look forward to the opportunities this funding will unlock for our current community and future generations.

The Australian Nepalese Multicultural Centre (ANMC) proudly participated in the ANZAC Day parade held in Melbourne on 25 April 2025.

ANMC President Dr Tilak Pokharel attended the ceremony and had the honour of laying a wreath in remembrance of those who served and sacrificed. He was joined by Immediate Past President Mr Gandhi Bhattarai and other ANMC members, standing in solidarity with The Brigade of Gurkhas.

The event was a moment to reflect on the deep connection between Nepalese soldiers and ANZAC history. The Gurkhas have a proud record of bravery and service during World War I, World War II, and many other conflicts, standing alongside Australian and Allied forces to protect world peace.

Dr Pokharel expressed heartfelt respect for the Gurkha soldiers, acknowledging their role in shaping the shared legacy of courage, resilience, and sacrifice. He also thanked veteran warrior Mr Bharansher Rai for the invitation and for arranging the wreath, making it possible for ANMC to participate meaningfully in the commemoration.

Participation in the ANZAC Day parade reinforces ANMC‚Äôs commitment to honouring history, promoting cultural connection, and contributing to the wider Australian community.

Lest we forget.

On Saturday, 21 June 2025, the Australian Nepalese Multicultural Centre (ANMC) welcomed members of the Whittlesea Interfaith Network for a visit focused on learning, cultural exchange, and interfaith understanding.

Ms. Amrita Gurung, Vice President of the Whittlesea Interfaith Network and Subeksha Shrestha facilitated the visit. The group was warmly received at the ANMC premises in Diggers Rest, where they explored the facilities and learned about ANMC‚Äôs role in preserving and promoting Nepalese culture and heritage in Victoria.

ANMC President Dr. Tilak Pokharel, Priest Narayan Gyawali, and long-time supporter Mr. Bharansher Rai led the welcome and shared the journey of ANMC, its history, purpose, and key initiatives. They highlighted ANMC‚Äôs role as a multicultural space for festivals, religious observances, and community events that bring together people from diverse backgrounds.

During the visit, guests and ANMC representatives engaged in meaningful discussions on:

  • The role of multicultural centres in supporting social cohesion
  • The growing importance of interfaith understanding in Victoria
  • Ways to collaborate for future programs and events that reflect shared values

Dr. Pokharel also extended a formal invitation to the guests to attend upcoming ANMC events, including the annual Teej Festival in August, which is one of the largest Nepalese cultural celebrations in Victoria.

Members of the ANMC Executive Committee and Engineering Sub-Committee were also present, showcasing the Centre‚Äôs teamwork and volunteer-led development efforts. The guests were particularly interested in the ongoing infrastructure projects and ANMC‚Äôs long-term masterplan to build a permanent cultural precinct.

The visit concluded with a shared commitment to build stronger relationships and continue working together to enhance the multicultural experience across Victoria. It was a reminder of how cultural dialogue, respect, and collaboration can help build more inclusive communities.

ANMC thanks Gurinder Kaur, President and the Whittlesea Interfaith Network family for their visit and looks forward to many more such meaningful exchanges.

On Sunday, 18 May 2025, the Australian Nepalese Multicultural Centre (ANMC) hosted a peaceful and meaningful Buddha Jayanti celebration at its Diggers Rest premises. The event marked the birth, enlightenment, and Parinirvana of Lord Gautam Buddha, born in Lumbini, Nepal ‚Äî a figure revered across the world as the Light of Peace.

This year‚Äôs celebration was a collaborative effort between ANMC, Tamang Society of Victoria, and Sherpa Association of Victoria, with strong support from ChildVerse, Lumbini-Kapilvastu Day Movement, Nepalese Association of Victoria (NAV), and NRNA Victoria.

The program welcomed members of Melbourne‚Äôs Buddhist, Nepali, and multicultural communities to take part in an afternoon filled with spiritual practice, cultural pride, and reflection.

Highlights of the Celebration:

  • Buddha Puja: A prayer session to honour Buddha‚Äôs teachings and path of compassion
  • Tseme (Sacred Flame) Lighting: Symbolising wisdom and the spreading of peace
  • Prayer Flags Hoisting (Lungdar Tabpa): Sharing blessings of compassion and hope
  • Prasad Distribution (Tshok Pulpa): Offering of sacred food to attendees
  • Vegetarian Bhojan: A shared meal, promoting peace and non-violence
  • Children‚Äôs Mindfulness Activities: Organised by ChildVerse, young participants engaged in journaling, breathing exercises, and reflection activities to learn about peace and inner calm in age-appropriate ways

The presence of different community organisations and volunteers reflected the values of Buddha‚Äôs teachings, cooperation, tolerance, and harmony. The event also served as a reminder of the shared cultural and spiritual heritage among many of Victoria‚Äôs communities.

ANMC thanks all the organisers, supporting organisations, and volunteers who made the event successful and peaceful. We look forward to building on this spirit of collaboration in future events that promote unity, culture, and mindfulness.

content.S:
On 6 July 2025, the Australian Nepalese Multicultural Centre (ANMC) hosted a special celebration of Tulasi Ropne Ekadashi at its premises in Diggers Rest. The event was held to mark the auspicious occasion of Harishayani Ekadashi, one of the most spiritually significant days in the Hindu calendar.

Harishayani Ekadashi, observed on the 11th day of the bright fortnight (Shukla Paksha) in the month of Ashadh, signifies the beginning of Chaturmas‚Äîthe four holy months.

The event, supported by the Nepalese Neighbourhood Community, featured several devotional and cultural activities:

  • Tulasi Puja ‚Äì A traditional worship ritual dedicated to the sacred Tulasi plant
  • Tulasi Plantation ‚Äì Symbolic planting to initiate the holy period of Chaturmas
  • Bhajan-Kirtan ‚Äì Soulful devotional singing led by community members
  • Evening Aarati ‚Äì A collective prayer with lighted lamps offering gratitude and reverence
  • Free Prasad Distribution ‚Äì Vegetarian offerings shared among all attendees

The calm and spiritual environment brought together families and devotees in reflection, devotion, and cultural connection.

ANMC extends its heartfelt thanks to all volunteers, participants, and partner organisations for making the event meaningful.

The Australian Nepalese Multicultural Centre (ANMC) is proud to announce that we have received funding from the Australian Federal Government under the Stronger Communities Programme. This funding will allow us to deliver a major upgrade to our facilities and digital presence by establishing a new website and enhanced social media presence, installing audio-visual and ICT equipment, upgrading electrical systems, and purchasing a defibrillator and first aid equipment.

This project will create a modern multimedia room paired with a user-friendly digital platform, strengthening ANMC‚Äôs role as a central community hub in the Hawke electorate. It will support newly arrived immigrants, people with disabilities, local families, students, and community groups. The multimedia room will feature advanced audio-visual and ICT tools to support education, cultural exchange, online connectivity, language training, cultural workshops, virtual conferences, and digital literacy programs. With the addition of first-aid equipment and improved disability access, ANMC will offer a safer, more inclusive space for all members of the community.

Our new interactive website will become a central communication hub, providing information on local services, community events, and educational opportunities. Multilingual resources will help newly arrived immigrants integrate into Australian society while enhancing digital literacy and reducing barriers to participation.

ANMC President Dr Tilak Pokharel said, ‚ÄúWe sincerely thank the Australian Federal Government and Sam Rae, MP, the Federal Member for Hawke, for their support. Their commitment to making ANMC accessible to more people is truly appreciated. ANMC is growing and becoming a multicultural hub for those who are interested in Nepali culture and heritage, and this project will help us welcome and engage even more members of our diverse community.‚Äù

Through this project, ANMC will expand opportunities for all, ensuring our community remains connected, inclusive, and equipped for the future.

content.S:
ANMC welcomed hundreds of Nepalese community members on 9 August 2025 to celebrate Janai Purnima and Rakshya Bandhan. The temple at Diggers Rest remained open from 6 am to 7 pm, giving devotees the opportunity to visit throughout the day for rituals and blessings.

Throughout the day, visitors came to receive the new sacred thread, or janai, and the protective wrist band, or rakshya sutra, from the guru. The atmosphere was filled with devotion as the sacred mantra echoed through the temple:

‡§Ü‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§û‡•ç‡§ö ‡§∂‡•Å‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç, ‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•ã‡§™‡§µ‡•Ä‡§§‡§Ç ‡§¨‡§≤‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§§‡•á‡§ú‡§É‡•§‡•§‚Äù

Janai Purnima, which falls on the full moon of the Nepali Shrawan month, is a day when Hindu men traditionally renew the sacred thread, while people of all backgrounds receive the rakshya sutra from the priest. The rituals are performed for purification, protection, and blessings for long life, wisdom, strength, and prosperity. In Nepal, the day is also associated with ritual baths, family gatherings, and enjoying the traditional kwati soup made from sprouted beans.

content.S:
Throughout the month of Shrawan, the fourth month of the Nepali calendar, ANMC celebrated all four Mondays dedicated to Lord Shiva. This year, Sawan Mondays fell on 5, 12, 19, and 26 Shrawan according to the solar calendar, concluding on 11 August 2025.

The ANMC welcomed a significantly large number of devotees each Monday, with many coming to pray, offer flowers, milk and bel leaves, and perform rituals dedicated to Lord Shiva. The atmosphere was filled with devotion, bhajans, and kirtans, creating a deeply spiritual environment.

For this year‚Äôs celebrations, the temple was blessed with the presence of Byasacharya Bhuwan Guru, who travelled from Nepal especially for the occasion. On the final Monday, a few hundred visitors attended. Devotees prayed to Lord Shiva, listened to the Shiva Katha narrated by Bhuwan Guru, and joined in the bhajan and kirtan sessions. The event concluded with the Maha Aarati, leaving the community united in faith and tradition.

In Hindu belief, Mondays in the month of Shrawan are considered especially dear to Lord Shiva. Observing the Monday fast during this month is believed to bring happiness, peace, prosperity, and the well-being of one‚Äôs family. Devotees perform special worship of Lord Shiva on these days, and according to astrology, Monday is ruled by Shiva, making worship on this day particularly auspicious. The tradition holds that fasting and prayers on Sawan Mondays yield special spiritual benefits.

Religious texts tell that Goddess Parvati attained Lord Shiva as her consort through the observance of the Monday fast, especially on days under the Hasta Nakshatra. In Hindu tradition, the month of Shrawan is considered the month of religious observance, and it is believed that acts of worship, charity, and fasting during this time bring multiplied spiritual merit.

content.S:
On 26 August 2025, the Australian Nepalese Multicultural Centre (ANMC) hosted one of the largest Nepali cultural gatherings ever held in Victoria. Despite the rain and strong winds, more than 5,000 people joined us at our Diggers Rest premises to celebrate Haritalika Teej with music, dance, rituals, and community spirit.

This year‚Äôs Teej was different. For the first time, major Nepali organisations in Victoria came together to host a single, shared event under the banner ‚ÄúTEEJ Together @ ANMC.‚Äù Co-organised by ANMC and Didi Bahini Samaj Victoria (DBSV), and in partnership with the Nepalese Association of Victoria (NAV) and NRNA Nari Nikunja Victoria, the event marked a milestone in unity and collaboration across our community.

Supported by the Victorian State Government, the Consulate Office of Nepal to Victoria, and many community organisations and local businesses, the festival highlighted what we can achieve when we work together.

The day was filled with vibrant performances, joyful dancing, and traditional rituals:

  • Shiva‚ÄìParvati Puja and Teej rituals brought women together in devotion and prayer.
  • Cultural and youth performances celebrated heritage while giving the younger generation a platform to connect with tradition.
  • Live music, DJ, and an open dance floor kept the energy alive throughout the day.
  • A free vegetarian feast was provided.
  • Activities of children.

This festival was only possible through the tireless efforts of many individuals and groups.

  • Volunteers managed every aspect from the kitchen to crowd management, temple operations, and line coordination with remarkable dedication.
  • Community organisations contributed their energy and support to ensure this celebration reflected the diversity of our community.
  • Sponsors and supporters, including many local businesses, helped make the event free and accessible for all.
  • Finally, we thank all Victorians who joined us, stood in the rain, and celebrated together as one.

content.S:
Australian Nepalese Multicultural Center (ANMC) has been honoured with the Community Organisation of the Year Award at the 2025 NRNA Excellence Awards. The award ceremony took place on Saturday, 6th September 2025 at the Hyatt Regency in Sydney. This national recognition celebrates ANMC‚Äôs outstanding contribution to the Nepali diaspora and wider multicultural community in Australia.

ANMC is one of the largest Nepali community organisations in Australia with more than 1,200 registered members. Since its establishment, ANMC has grown into a leading hub for culture, religion, social connection, and community service. The centre operates on a 15-acre land in Diggers Rest, Victoria, making it the first and only Nepali organisation in Australia with such a facility. It has become a true home for the community and a place where culture, traditions, and values are shared.

Every year, ANMC organises more than 50 events, from major festivals such as Teej, Dashain, Tihar, Shivaratri and Janmashtami to youth forums, senior gatherings, and women‚Äôs programs. These events bring together more than 10,000 participants annually, offering opportunities to unite, celebrate, and share values. Beyond cultural celebrations, ANMC delivers food relief programs and distributes essentials to international students and families in need, alongside regular prasad distribution during religious activities.

The organisation also provides a platform for young people, women, and seniors to lead and showcase their talents while building stronger intergenerational connections. Its leadership and programs have made ANMC a key partner for the Victorian Government in multicultural engagement. By hosting large-scale, well-organised events, ANMC has reshaped how MPs, Ministers, and multicultural leaders view the Nepali community, highlighting its role as a significant contributor to multicultural Victoria.

This award is a reflection of the dedication and hard work of ANMC‚Äôs members, volunteers, and community partners. As President Tilak Pokharel expressed, ‚ÄúThis award reflects the dedication and hard work of our members, volunteers, and community partners. It is a proud moment for all of us and a milestone in our journey of service, unity, and cultural celebration.‚Äù

ANMC extends its gratitude to the NRNA Australia Awards Committee for this recognition and to all community members for their ongoing support. The organisation will continue to serve with inclusivity and dedication, building on this milestone to expand programs, strengthen facilities, and create more opportunities for cultural preservation, social connection, and community wellbeing.

content.S:
Indra Jatra ‚Äì Yenya Punhi 2025 was celebrated on 6th September 2025 at the Australian Nepalese Multicultural Centre in Diggers Rest with great pride and participation. For the first time outside Nepal, the festival was organised in its full traditional form by Newa Guthi Melbourne, with ANMC as a proud partner and host.

The event brought together community members, cultural groups, and leaders from across Victoria to witness and take part in one of Nepal‚Äôs most significant festivals. Indra Jatra is not only a vibrant celebration but also a symbol of identity, unity, and heritage. Hosting it at ANMC highlighted the Centre‚Äôs role as a home for cultural exchange, learning, and connection.

ANMC has always worked with the Nepali communities of Victoria to preserve and promote language, traditions, and values, and to pass them on to future generations. Events like Indra Jatra show how culture can thrive in Australia when organisations and communities work hand in hand.

We sincerely thank Newa Guthi Melbourne for their leadership, our distinguished guests for joining us, and all the volunteers who dedicated their time and effort to make the day a success. Most of all, thank you to every participant whose presence gave life and meaning to the festival.

title.S: Indra Jatra 2025 Celebrated at ANMC with Historic Significance

content.S:
Today was a historic day for the Australian Nepalese Multicultural Centre (ANMC) as we welcomed Hon. Ingrid Stitt, Minister for Multicultural Affairs, along with local MPs Josh Bull and Kathleen Matthews-Ward, to our centre in Diggers Rest.

The Minister, together with Josh and Kathleen, joined us for a special meeting before the Indra Jatra celebration. ANMC President Dr. Tilak Pokharel presented the achievements of ANMC and outlined the proposal for the ANMC Multicultural Hall Project. Minister Stitt praised the dedication of the Nepali community and expressed her commitment, along with the government‚Äôs, to supporting ANMC‚Äôs work. Josh Bull acknowledged ANMC‚Äôs significant contribution to his electorate and committed to assisting the Multicultural Hall project. Kathleen Matthews-Ward also expressed her support and confirmed that she would work closely with the Minister and Josh to progress the proposal.

We sincerely thank Hon. Consul Nirajan Gauli for facilitating this important meeting.

Later, during the vibrant Indra Jatra celebration, we were honoured to welcome Deputy Opposition Leader and Shadow Minister for Multicultural Affairs Evan Mulholland and Steve McGhie MP. Their encouragement and recognition of ANMC‚Äôs work and the Nepali community‚Äôs contribution were deeply appreciated.

ANMC extends heartfelt thanks to Newa Guthi Melbourne for their tireless efforts and collaboration in organising Indra Jatra, which brought together thousands of community members to celebrate culture, tradition, and togetherness.

This day marks a milestone for ANMC and strengthens our resolve to build the Multicultural Hall as a landmark for all communities in Victoria.

content.S:
The main celebration day of the Dashain, Tihar and Chhath Festival 2024 was held on Sunday, 26 September at the Australian Nepalese Multicultural Center (ANMC). The event attracted participants from different parts of Victoria and from various community groups.

The program featured multicultural performances that represented the diversity of the broader community. There were Panche Baja performances and several other stage performances by Nepali and other cultural organisations.

For the convenience of visitors, ANMC organised free bus shuttles from different suburbs across Victoria. This helped families and community members easily attend the event and enjoy the festivities together.

For the very first time, ANMC installed a Rote Ping (Ferris wheel) at the venue. There were also several other activities for children and adults, making the celebration enjoyable for all age groups.

The main day successfully showcased the multicultural spirit of the Nepali community in Australia and reflected ANMC‚Äôs goal of promoting unity through shared cultural celebration.

title.S: Celebration of Dashain, Tihar and Chhath Festival 2024 (26 September)

content.S:
The Australian Nepalese Multicultural Center (ANMC) celebrated Dashain, Tihar and Chhath Festival 2024 from 22 September to 1 October. The event ran for nine days and brought together the community for daily religious and cultural activities.

Every day, Bhuwan Guru delivered Devi Bhagwat Katha Bachan, which was attended by devotees from different parts of Victoria. There were Durga Puja, Bhajan, Aarati and Prasad distribution each day at the ANMC temple.

Special pujas were performed on the main days of the festival, including Fulpati, Maha Saptami, Maha Asthami, Maha Nawami, Bijaya Dashami and Kanya Puja. The temple remained open for visitors throughout the week, and volunteers helped in organising puja, prasad and temple management.

On the tenth day of Nawa Durga, ANMC distributed Jamara to community members who came to receive blessings. The festival created an environment of devotion and unity and allowed the community to celebrate important cultural traditions together in Australia.

content.S:
The Australian Nepalese Multicultural Center (ANMC) celebrated Shree Krishna Janmashtami Lila Mahotsav on Saturday, 16 August 2025 (31 Shrawan 2082) at its premises in Diggers Rest. The event was filled with devotion, cultural expression, and community participation.

The celebration included the following main activities:

  • Krishna Katha by Byasacharya Bhuwan Guru
  • Jhanki Lila (Krishna-Radha cultural depiction)
  • Bhajan Kirtan by local devotees
  • Maha Aarati and Nandotsav

The program started at 4 PM and continued until 8 PM. Devotees attended in large numbers with their families and children dressed in Krishna and Radha attire, adding color and joy to the celebration.

In addition, continuous Bhajan Kirtan was held from Friday 7 PM to Saturday 1 AM, where devotees sang devotional songs and offered prayers.

The event created a warm and spiritual atmosphere and strengthened cultural and religious connection among the Nepali community in Australia.

content.S:
The Bal Diwas (Children‚Äôs Day) program was successfully held on Saturday, 18 October 2025, at the Australian Nepalese Multicultural Center (ANMC) in collaboration with the Nepalese Association of Victoria (NAV). The event celebrated the talents, creativity, and enthusiasm of children studying in various Nepali community schools across Victoria.

The program ran from 9:30 AM to 4:00 PM at the ANMC premises and featured a full day of activities, including:

  • Cultural parade
  • Stage performances by children
  • Entertainment games and fun activities

The event was inaugurated with Swasti Vachan and lighting of the Panas (traditional lamp).
Deputy Mayor of Melton City Council, Cr. Lara Carli, attended as the chief guest and expressed her joy seeing the children‚Äôs participation and cultural spirit.

NAV President Dr. Yakindra Timilsena thanked all schools, parents, and volunteers for making this year‚Äôs event even more engaging and child-friendly.

Representatives from 15 Nepali schools participated, including:
NAV Bal Chautari North, DMNC, West, Wyndham, Lynbrook, Everest, Laverton, Hamro Nepali Pathshala, Bal Vatika Epping-Wollert, Craigieburn Nepali Ethnic School, Hamro Barnamala, Bal Sansar Glenroy, Bhutanese Nepali Ethnic School Melbourne (BNESM), and Cranbourne Gyanjyoti Pathshala.

The event was attended by Honorary Consul of Nepal for Victoria Mr. Nirajan Gauli, Melton Deputy Mayor Cr. Lara Carli, ANMC President Dr. Tilak Pokharel, NRNA Victoria Coordinator Mr. Mahadev Dhanuk, and several community leaders and educators.

NAV and ANMC thanked all sponsors, supporters, volunteers, and schools for their contribution to making the 2025 Bal Diwas a memorable and successful community event.

content.S:
The Nepalese Madheshi Community Victoria (NMCV) celebrated Chhath Parba at the Australian Nepalese Multicultural Centre (ANMC) in Diggers Rest on 27 and 28 October 2025. The event was supported by ANMC and attended by a large number of devotees and community members from across Victoria.

Chhath Parba is one of the most important Hindu festivals dedicated to the Sun God, Surya, and Chhathi Maiya. It is celebrated to express gratitude for life, energy and wellbeing. The festival involves strict fasting, ritual bathing, and offering prayers to the setting and rising sun.

The celebration began on Monday evening, 27 October, with offerings to the setting sun. The following morning, 28 October, devotees gathered again before sunrise to complete the ritual by making offerings to the rising sun. The devotion, discipline and cultural unity displayed during the ceremony created a peaceful and spiritual environment at ANMC.

ANMC thanked NMCV for organising the event and all devotees and volunteers for their participation. The celebration once again showed how ANMC continues to serve as a cultural home for all Nepalese communities in Australia.

content.S:
The Australian Nepalese Multicultural Centre (ANMC) is a community organisation dedicated to preserving and promoting Nepali culture and heritage in Australia. The ANMC Temple serves as a spiritual home for the Nepali and broader community , conducting daily worship services and celebrating major Nepali Hindu festivals.

We are currently seeking multiple dedicated and experienced Temple Priests (Pujari) to join our community in Melbourne, Victoria.

About the Role

The Temple Priest is responsible for performing daily worship and rituals, maintaining the spiritual and physical order of the temple, and providing religious and cultural guidance to devotees. The successful candidates will work closely with the ANMC Executive Committee to ensure the temple operates in accordance with Hindu traditions and ANMC‚Äôs established policies.

This is a minimum one-year contract position with the possibility of renewal , commencing in December 2025 or as mutually agreed.

Key Responsibilities Include:

  • Performing daily morning and evening worship, including puja and aarti, on time and with proper procedure.
  • Officiating religious ceremonies and major festivals such as Dashain, Tihar, Teej, Janmashtami, and Shivaratri.
  • Maintaining the temple‚Äôs cleanliness and spiritual purity, including caring for idols, altars, and prayer materials.
  • Providing blessings, answering religious queries, and guiding devotees respectfully.
  • Keeping records of rituals and donations and maintaining the temple calendar.
  • Assisting in promoting temple activities and participating in community programs.

Mandatory Requirements

All applicants must hold the following:

  • ANMC Life Membership.
  • A valid Victorian Working With Children Check (WWCC).
  • A current National Police Check.
  • An ABN and Public Liability insurance.

Qualifications and Skills

  • Demonstrated expertise in Hindu rituals and Vedic traditions, particularly those practiced in Nepal.
  • Strong knowledge of Sanskrit and fluency in both Nepali and English (reading, writing, and speaking).
  • Familiarity with Nepali cultural and festival practices.
  • Prior experience as a temple priest or community religious officiant is preferred.
  • Basic computer literacy for records and communication.

Remuneration

ANMC will pay the priest at an hourly rate on ABN for services at the temple , with additional payment for specific religious rituals conducted. All fees, dakshina, and donations made at the temple are the property of ANMC.

How to Apply

Applicants must submit the following documents to info@anmcinc.org.au :

  1. A detailed resume.
  2. A cover letter explaining your ritual experience, cultural understanding, and motivation to serve at ANMC.
  3. Copies of your WWCC and Police Check (or intension of application).
  4. Contact details of referees and any relevant certifications.

Applications Close: Friday, December 12, 2025.

Only shortlisted candidates will be invited for an interview and assessment.

Please download the full Position Description for complete details on the role, working conditions, and financial protocols.
